dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a pretty stark contrast, isn't it? The Eurozone's productivity nearly tripled, while the US actually fell by over 6%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a pretty stark contrast, isn't it? The Eurozone's productivity nearly tripled, while the U S actually fell by over six percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And that's just wild, right? Because you'd think with all the talk of American innovation, we'd be leading the pack, not lagging behind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's just wild, right? Because you'd think with all the talk of American innovation, we'd be leading the pack, not lagging behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And one theory is that it's because of the lack of fiscal stimulus in the US during the pandemic, but that doesn't totally add up for me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And one theory is that it's because of the lack of fiscal stimulus in the U S during the pandemic, but that doesn't totally add up for me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, if anything, you'd expect tight labor markets to force companies to invest in efficiency, not the other way around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, if anything, you'd expect tight labor markets to force companies to invest in efficiency, not the other way around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But instead, it seems like firms here are just hiring more people instead of upgrading tech. I mean, have you been to a bank lately? So many tellers, so few ATMs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But instead, it seems like firms here are just hiring more people instead of upgrading tech. I mean, have you been to a bank lately? So many tellers, so few ATMs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, don't even get me started on those handwritten menus at restaurants. It feels like we're going backwards sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, don't even get me started on those handwritten menus at restaurants. It feels like we're going backwards sometimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then again, this trend started before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as loose. So there's gotta be something else going on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then again, this trend started before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as loose. So there's gotta be something else going on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Maybe it's tech adoption? The article points out that US firms have been slow to capitalize on digital technologies, especially since the financial crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Maybe it's tech adoption? The article points out that U S firms have been slow to capitalize on digital technologies, especially since the financial crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, while American firms have been quicker to capitalize on digital technologies, the timing is wrong here, too: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now with AI, it's like they've fully mastered how to slow productivity growth with it? That's almost impressive in a depressing way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now with A I, it's like they've fully mastered how to slow productivity growth with it? That's almost impressive in a depressing way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As for the latest round of new digital technologies, firms are only just now beginning to explore how large language models and generative artificial intelligence can be used to boost productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the whole productivity J-curve thing—where you take a hit before seeing gains—seems to be hitting the US harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the whole productivity J-curve thing-where you take a hit before seeing gains-seems to be hitting the U S harder.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Europe's somehow surging ahead. Maybe their data privacy rules are accidentally encouraging AI development?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Europe's somehow surging ahead. Maybe their data privacy rules are accidentally encouraging A I development?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or maybe they just got lucky with energy prices thanks to Putin? Lower costs let them restructure and invest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or maybe they just got lucky with energy prices thanks to Putin? Lower costs let them restructure and invest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Mario Draghi—he's supposed to propose ways to boost productivity, but the article sarcastically says he'll probably do the opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Mario Draghi-he's supposed to propose ways to boost productivity, but the article sarcastically says he'll probably do the opposite.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies. Draghi will recommend removing barriers to competition, which would intensify the pressure on firms to innovate in order to survive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like abandon capital markets or reduce competition. But obviously that's not gonna help.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like abandon capital markets or reduce competition. But obviously that's not gonna help.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So Europe's riding a wave of good policies and maybe some luck, while the US is stuck in a low-productivity rut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Europe's riding a wave of good policies and maybe some luck, while the U S is stuck in a low-productivity rut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a sobering comparison, honestly. Makes you wonder what it'll take for the US to turn things around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a sobering comparison, honestly. Makes you wonder what it'll take for the U S to turn things around.

A sharp divergence in productivity growth between the US and the Eurozone since 2004.

HostA: And that’s just wild, right? Because you'd think with all the talk of American innovation, we'd be leading the pack, not lagging behind.
HostB: Exactly. And one theory is that it’s because of the lack of fiscal stimulus in the US during the pandemic, but that doesn't totally add up for me.

HostB: But instead, it seems like firms here are just hiring more people instead of upgrading tech. I mean, have you been to a bank lately? So many tellers, so few ATMs.
HostA: Ugh, don't even get me started on those handwritten menus at restaurants. It feels like we're going backwards sometimes.
HostB: But then again, this trend started before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as loose. So there's gotta be something else going on.
HostA: Maybe it's tech adoption? The article points out that US firms have been slow to capitalize on digital technologies, especially since the financial crisis.
HostB: And now with AI, it's like they've fully mastered how to slow productivity growth with it? That’s almost impressive in a depressing way.
HostA: Yeah, the whole productivity J-curve thing—where you take a hit before seeing gains—seems to be hitting the US harder.
HostB: Meanwhile, Europe's somehow surging ahead. Maybe their data privacy rules are accidentally encouraging AI development?
HostA: Or maybe they just got lucky with energy prices thanks to Putin? Lower costs let them restructure and invest.
HostB: And then there's Mario Draghi—he's supposed to propose ways to boost productivity, but the article sarcastically says he'll probably do the opposite.
HostA: Right, like abandon capital markets or reduce competition. But obviously that's not gonna help.
HostB: So Europe's riding a wave of good policies and maybe some luck, while the US is stuck in a low-productivity rut.
